image.altText: A bushfire is seen in the background behind a sandbar on a quiet beach

props.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with hundreds of firefighters battling multiple blazes in Victoria while an emergency warning has been issued for Flinders Island in Tasmania's north-east. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in Victoria and Tasmania reach emergency level as residents told to keep watch

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rain is helping firefighters in Flinders Island, Tasmania, where an out of control bushfire has been downgraded from an emergency level warning to watch and act. ABC Hobart reporter Loretta Lohberger says the fire in the island's northwest has been burning near the communities of Leeka and Pine Scrub since Sunday. "It has damaged power poles and destroyed a caravan, and firefighters actively defended four properties last night," she says. Stephen Richardson from the Tasmania Fire Service says patrols are continuing. "We still have to continue to monitor the fire in and around those properties because there's not enough rain to extinguish the fire at this point," he says. He says smoke from the fire extended across parts of the Tasmanian mainland, including Launceston and Deloraine .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rain is helping firefighters in Flinders Island as patrols continue

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victoria's new Deputy Premier and Education Minister Ben Carroll says the fires have forced seven schools to close in the Gippsland area. "We're doing everything we can to support those students, teachers and families. "We're urging everyone to follow the advice and stay home and do everything you can to be safe." Our ABC Gippsland reporter William Howard says ash is falling from the sky in Loch Sport, with residents and visitors told it is too late to leave. He says the single access road in and out of the area has been closed, while power to the town is cut. "In Briagolong, the fire has more than trippled in size overnight, burning across 17,000 hectares," he says. "Heavy rainfall is on the way, but CFA Chief Officer Jason Heffernan says strong winds are creating a dynamic fire situation. "A relief centre has been set up in Sale for anyone requiring assistance."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Seven schools in Eastern Victoria forced to close

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Firefighters are still working to control a blaze that swept across an area containing unexploded WWII bombs in northern New South Wales. The fire is one of 82 now burning across the state, and is listed by the Rural Fire Services (RFS) as being controlled. The fire broke out on Friday south of Evans Head and quickly moved into the Bundjalung National Park, threatening the campground and forcing visitors to leave the area. By Monday, it had tore through an RAAF air weapons range, which is used for bombing exercises at certain times of the year. You can read the full story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fireys forced to stand down as fire sweeps over area containing unexploded WWII bombs

featuredLink.title: Firefighters stand down as fire sweeps over RAAF air weapons range

The similarity in the colour scheme was noticed at a polling station on Monday. You can read more here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A huge statewide effort is underway to fight several out of control bushfires which are spreading across Gippsland. At least 650 firefighters are battling hot and windy weather conditions, with a cool change not expected until later this afternoon. A fire at Loch Sport jumped the Longford-Loch Sport Road and has burned 3,000 hectares. Electricity to the town has been cut and the only access in and out of the area has been closed. Incident controller Andy Gillan says it is too late to leave. "Those Loch Sport people please remain vigilant, shelter in place, enact your fire plans and if you're feeling uncomfortable in Loch Sport we encourage you to head down to the Marina Hotel. " You can keep up to date with the Gippsland fires here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Statewide effort underway as bushfires spread across Gippsland

featuredLink.title: With their only road out of town now cut by bushfire, residents prepare for possible evacuation by boat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Late-night talk shows are returning after a five-month absence brought on by the Hollywood writers strike. CBS's The Late Show With Stephen Colbert, ABC's Jimmy Kimmel Live! and NBC's T he Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon were the first shows to leave the air when the writers strike began on May 2, and now will be among the first to return on Monday night. Comedian John Oliver got his first take on the strike out, exuberantly returning Sunday night to his Last Week Tonight show on HBO and delivering full-throated support for the strike. Oliver cheerily delivered a recap of stories from the last five months before getting serious, calling the strike "an immensely difficult time" for all those in the industry. "To be clear, this strike happened for good reasons. Our industry has seen its workers severely squeezed in recent years," Oliver said. "So, the writers guild went to strike and thankfully won. But, it took a lot of sacrifices from a lot of people to achieve that. "I am also furious that it took the studios 148 days to achieve a deal they could have offered on day one," Oliver said. He added that he hopes the writers contract would give leverage to other entertainment industry guilds – as well as striking car workers and employees in other industries – to negotiate better deals. Network late-night hosts will have their returns later on Monday. The writers were allowed to return to work last week after the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement on a three-year contract with an alliance of the industry's biggest studios, streaming services and production companies. Reporting by AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US late-night talk show hosts return after five-month absence

props.alt: Four white men in suits stand side by side.

children.content: Jimmy Fallon (left), Jimmy Kimmel, Seth Meyers and Stephen Colbert will be returning to their late night shows.
(AP)

got his first take on the strike out, exuberantly returning Sunday night to his Last Week Tonight show on HBO and delivering full-throated support for the strike.
Oliver cheerily delivered a recap of stories from the last five months before getting serious, calling the strike "an immensely difficult time" for all those in the industry.
"To be clear, this strike happened for good reasons. Our industry has seen its workers severely squeezed in recent years," Oliver said.
"So, the writers guild went to strike and thankfully won. But, it took a lot of sacrifices from a lot of people to achieve that.
"I am also furious that it took the studios 148 days to achieve a deal they could have offered on day one," Oliver said.
He added that he hopes the writers contract would give leverage to other entertainment industry guilds – as well as striking car workers and employees in other industries – to negotiate better deals.
Network late-night hosts will have their returns later on Monday.

The writers were allowed to return to work last week after the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement on a three-year contract with an alliance of the industry's biggest studios, streaming services and production companies.
Reporting by AP

props.synopsis: The local share market falls sharply as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the value of the Australian dollar, gold and oil suffer heavy losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX falls sharply, Australian dollar sinks to 11-month low ahead of Reserve Bank decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has recovered some of its earlier losses, but it's still very much in negative territory. The ASX 200 was down 1.4% to 6,936 points, by 12:25pm AEDT. Healthcare is the only sector trading higher, led by gains from Resmed (+1.2%) and CSL (+1%). Mining and energy stocks are still the worst performers, including Perseus Mining (-4.8%), Beach Energy (-4.8%) and Evolution Mining (-4.4%), after a big drop in gold and oil prices overnight. The Australian dollar is trading at 63.55 US cents (having lost more than 1% overnight), and remains near an 11-month low.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets at midday: ASX 200 down 1.4 per cent

, by 12:25pm AEDT.

CSL

Evolution Mining
(-4.4%), after a big drop in gold and oil prices overnight.
The Australian dollar is trading at 63.55 US cents (having lost more than 1% overnight), and remains near an 11-month low.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Share market across the world have performed quite badly in the past three months. Several major indexes posted their biggest quarterly (and monthly) losses all year: So what's causing investors to get spooked? One factor is the comments that central bank officials, worldwide have made about the interest rate outlook. Earlier today, Federal Reserve Vice Chair for Supervision Michael Barr said he feels US rates are "at or near" a level that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to the Fed's 2% target. It is also likely, he told the Forecasters Club of New York, that rates will need to stay high for some time to bring inflation down to target, and he is confident the Fed will get that job done. Senior officials from the US, European, British and Australian central banks have recently made similar statements (reiterating that the next move on rates is "data dependent"), which aren't exactly groundbreaking. Investors are now beginning to take them more seriously, and are re-thinking their earlier expectations about rate cuts happening soon. Bond sell-off, stronger US greenback, weaker share markets So the "higher for longer" narrative has caused a sell-off in the government bond (or debt) market, which has pushed the US 10-year Treasury yield to its highest level in 16 years (around the time of the Global Financial Crisis). As the price of bonds fall, their yields go up (the price and yield move in opposite directions). It means the US government would need to pay higher interest, to entice more people to lend it money (by purchasing its Treasurey bonds). And that boosted the US dollar to its highest level since November last year (and weakened other currencies, like the Australian dollar, in the process). As more investors invest in the 'safe' greenback, they're pulling their money out of riskier assets (like the share market), which is why the ASX 200, S & P 500, Stoxx 600, Nikkei and other indexes suffered their worst quarters of the year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why are stock markets doing so poorly ... while the US dollar is surging

children.content: Share market across the world have performed quite badly in the past three months.
Several major indexes posted their biggest quarterly (and monthly) losses all year:
So what's causing investors to get spooked?
One factor is the comments that central bank officials, worldwide have made about the interest rate outlook.
Earlier today, Federal Reserve Vice Chair for Supervision Michael Barr said he feels US rates are "at or near" a level that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to the Fed's 2% target.
It is also likely, he told the Forecasters Club of New York, that rates will need to
stay high for some time
to bring inflation down to target, and he is confident the Fed will get that job done.

Senior officials from the US, European, British and Australian central banks have recently made similar statements (reiterating that the next move on rates is "data dependent"), which aren't exactly groundbreaking.
Investors are now beginning to take them more seriously, and are re-thinking their earlier expectations about rate cuts happening soon.
Bond sell-off, stronger US greenback, weaker share markets

So the "higher for longer" narrative has caused a sell-off in the government bond (or debt) market, which has pushed the US 10-year Treasury yield to its highest level in 16 years (around the time of the Global Financial Crisis).
As the price of bonds fall, their yields go up (the price and yield move in opposite directions).

props.alt: A line graph showing the cost of borrowing money for the US government has surged to a 16-year high.

children.content: The US 10-year Treasury yield surged to its highest level since late 2007.
(Yahoo! Finance)
It means the US government would need to pay higher interest, to entice more people to lend it money (by purchasing its Treasurey bonds).
And that boosted the US dollar to its highest level since November last year (and weakened other currencies, like the Australian dollar, in the process).
As more investors invest in the 'safe' greenback, they're pulling their money out of riskier assets (like the share market), which is why the ASX 200, S
P 500, Stoxx 600, Nikkei and other indexes suffered their worst quarters of the year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The competition regulator has thrown up a hurdle to a potential healthcare takover deal. Australian Clinical Labs (ACL) wants to buy medical centre operator Healius. However, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commmission ( ACCC ) said today that it has "significant preliminary competition concerns", and that the deal could reduce competition for pathology services. ACL may need to sell off its approved collection centres (for pathology services) across the nation before the Healius buyout can be approved. "We are now seeking feedback from stakeholders on whether the draft undertaking offered by ACL would be capable of addressing the competition concerns," ACCC commissioner Stephen Ridgeway said. The proposed buyout may involve ACL divesting 60 of its pathology collection centres in Perth, 25 across regional Victoria, and 14 in the Northern Territory (subject to a final decision by the regulator). Shares of Healius fell 2.4% to $2.23, while Australian Clinical Labs is down 1.4% to $2.76.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian Clinical's proposed takeover of Healius complicated by ACCC's demands

children.content: The competition regulator has thrown up a hurdle to a potential healthcare takover deal.
Australian Clinical Labs
(ACL) wants to buy medical centre operator
Healius
However, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commmission (
ACCC
) said today that it has "significant preliminary competition concerns", and that the deal could reduce competition for pathology services.
ACL may need to sell off its approved collection centres (for pathology services) across the nation before the Healius buyout can be approved.
"We are now seeking feedback from stakeholders on whether the draft undertaking offered by ACL would be capable of addressing the competition concerns," ACCC commissioner Stephen Ridgeway said.

The proposed buyout may involve ACL divesting 60 of its pathology collection centres in Perth, 25 across regional Victoria, and 14 in the Northern Territory (subject to a final decision by the regulator).
Shares of Healius fell 2.4% to $2.23, while Australian Clinical Labs is down 1.4% to $2.76.
